elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME.
1. INT. KALA’S QUARTERS.
DISTURBED BY A SHRILL COMMUNICATOR ALERT. CONTROLLER
TACE STIRS IN BED.
(FORCING HERSELF AWAKE) What sort of time is this...?
TAPS THE COMMUNICATOR.
(DISTORT) Controller, it’s Darin Fell.
General?
Sorry to disturb you, but I have wonderful news. They’re coming back!
Who’s coming — [back]? (SUDDENLY WIDE AWAKE) The Johannes (yo- HANNUS) Kepler??
It just showed up on the long-range detectors!
CLIMBS QUICKLY FROM HER BED.
I’1ll see you in the Control Suite directly.
(D) See you shortly.
THE CHANNEL CLOSES.
My Gods. They’re alive!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 3
2. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
TARDIS IN FLIGHT.
Directional Unit... (PUSHES BUTTON) .. on. Atomic accelerator... (PULLS LEVER) .. engaged.
Well done, Adric. You’re now flying the TARDIS.
Right...
Go on, Adric. It’s all perfectly logical.
(SARCASTIC) Yeah, right. Good luck.
Relax, Adric. Remember what I’ve taught you.
We’re approaching a planetary cluster. (TURNS A DIAL) Adjusting the helmic regulator three degrees.
Compensating for local gravity. Excellent.
PRESSES BUTTONS.
Inputting navigation sequence.
We’re still within a star system. You should wait until we’re in open space before — [you do that]
It’s alright, I checked. Navigation sequence... (PUSHES BUTTON) activated.
SURGE. ROOM PITCHES VIOLENTLY.
DOCTOR, NYSSA AND TEGAN: (THROWN) Aaagh!!
What did you do?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 4
(PANICKY) I can’t stop it!!
Look at the scanner! We’re heading for a supernova!
Adjust course, Adric! Now!!
HITS CONTROLS.
The controls won’t respond!! Maybe if I — !
Too late! We’re going to hit!!
A CATACLYSMIC IMPACT. THE ENGINES CUT OUT. A FEW MOMENTS’ SILENCE. THEN —
Well done, Adric. You killed us.
Again.
SOLrry...
(TRYING TO BE POSITIVE) We lasted longer than last time.
You made the simulation too hard.
I recreated a typical area of space.
You’re never going to let me fly it for real, are you?
Don’t be downhearted. Flying a TARDIS is complicated. You don’t just press a button and hope, you know.
Could have fooled me.
Space/Time travel is logarithms, geometry, trigonometry. All the mathematical disciplines at once.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 5
It sounds impossible.
I’m sure it’s not, for someone with a badge for mathematical excellence.
Then why can’t I get it right?
A little more homework is all that’s required. Perhaps a visit to somewhere with experts in astronomical navigation? As it happens, I know just the place. Not far from here.
Where is ‘here’, anyway?
Interspace.
You what?
The space between galaxies. Perfect for TARDIS flying lessons. Between the Milky Way — your galaxy, Tegan — and two of your nearest neighbours. Let me just reset the scanner... (OPERATES
RESETS WITH A FLOURISH.
It’s beautiful!
That’s a galaxy? A whole galaxy?
That, Tegan, is the Large Magellanic Cloud. [NB: PRONOUNCED ‘majuh-LANNIC’.] Known as the L.M.C.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 6
3. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
HIVE OF ACTIVITY. OPERATIVES AT WORKSTATIONS. KALA STRIDES IN.
We won’t be needing your rescue mission after all, General.
I still say we should have sent a military force in the first place.
We'll judge that once we know what happened out there. Where’s the Kepler now?
Six kiloparsecs out, on a reciprocal course from the L.M.C.
Do we have contact?
Not yet.
But at six K.P.C., they’re well within range.
We’re getting no response to our calls.
How long until they arrive?
FX: FELL TAPS A FEW BUTTONS ON THE COMPUTER SCREEN. BEEP BEEP.
Doesn't look like they’re using their Leap Drive. At current rate, I’d say about three hours.
I want the base on full readiness. Lock it down. No visitors, no students. Not until we’ve received the Kepler.
Right away.
In fact, nothing until we find out what the devil happened to that ship. — Just what did they find in the L.M.C....?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
4. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
It’s so colourful.
Page 7
Those areas of pink are where new stars are being formed,
burning hydrogen.
It’s like a star factory.
I’ve not heard of the L.M.C. before.
Living in Australia, you might have seen Magellanic Cloud — that’s out there too, thousand light years into space.
They can be seen from Earth?
From the southern hemisphere.
Are we going there?
No, we're heading to Gallius Ultima.
TAPS CONTROLS.
What’s Gallius Ultima?
it. And the Small another thirty
A planet on the edge of the Milky Way. Known to those who live and work there as ‘Gallius U’. It’s a research station, housing one of the most impressive astronomical observatories ever
built.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 8
5. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
PRESSES A COMMUNICATOR SWITCH.
(INTO MIC) This is Gallius U calling the Johannes Kepler. Please respond.
STATIC.
Still nothing.
It might be they can receive, but not transmit.
How far out are they now?
(CHECKS) Two kiloparsecs.
Can we get visual?
Not at that distance. The probe satellites aren’t up to it.
If they’re not, I know what might be...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 9
6. INT. ARRIVALS HUB.
SPACIOUS, HIGH-CEILINGED AREA. TARDIS MATERIALISES. DOCTOR, ADRIC, NYSSA AND TEGAN STEP OUT.
This isn’t getting me to Heathrow.

Oh Tegan. I’m broadening your mind. We’re in the fifty-third century, when humanity is still contained within its own galaxy. In a century or so they’1ll discover intergalactic drives and make the next great leap. Gallius Ultima is where they’1l make that leap from.
HE SHUTS DOOR.
All those corridors. It could be the Starliner.
Where have we landed, exactly?
We’re at the heart of the research base. Visitors arrive here, then take one of these passages to reach the different zones. Or Hubs, as they call them.
How are you meant to know which one leads where?

In this time, the custom is to use ideograms rather than written signs. (POINTING) That symbol there - the one with the arrow pointing backwards - that represents History. A little enigmatic, perhaps.
And that one? A circle in... (COUNTS) .. twelve segments.
Astrology.
So they’re into that type of stargazing?
This is ‘the Planet at the Edge of the Galaxy’. It draws all sorts — the scientific, the spiritual, the adventurous and the curious.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 10
The scientific alongside the spiritual.. and they work together?
Both looking for answers, in their own way. But not always to the same question.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 11
7. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
TACE ENTERS.
(ENTERING) Mother. You called me.
Autumn. We need to get sight of the Kepler, but the probe satellites haven’t got the range.
I could go to Astronomy, and redirect the orbital telescope? That should get an image.
Exactly what I was hoping.
(LEAVING) I’1l be as quick as I can.
HURRIES OUT.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 12
8. INT. ARRIVALS HUB.
Where are all the visitors?
In the Hubs, I imagine.
So. This way leads to the Astrology Zone. Sorry, Hub. This way to History... and the others?
Let me see... (TRANSLATING SYMBOLS) “Humanities”... “Exploration”... "Viewing Deck”...
Viewing deck? With a view of what?
The base. The Hubs and the land around them.
We came here for astronomy, didn’t we?
I think I’ve found the ideogram for that. A star. Not as indecipherable as most.
Well spotted, Nyssa.
Let’s go there, then.
Can’t we go to the Viewing Deck first?
WALKS OFF DOWN A PASSAGE.
You do what you like. I’m going to Astronomy.
Adric!
It’s alright, I’1ll go with him.
WALKS OFF DOWN ANOTHER PASSAGE.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 13
Well, I’m off to this Viewing Deck. See you in a bit.
Tegan...!
Go with her, Doctor. Join us later. (WALKS OFF)
EXASPERATED) One day they’1ll all do as I Say... (ENTERS PASSAGE
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 14
9. INT. MONORAIL DECK.
A SMALL, CONTAINED MONORAIL TERMINUS. ADRIC AND NYSSA ENTER.
What’s this?
A transportation capsule, I think. It’d seem to run on that Single rail, see?
We must have to use this to get to Astronomy.
HE OPENS A TOP CANOPY ON A FOUR-PERSON POD AND CLIMBS IN.
(CLIMBING IN) Come on, get in.
CLIMBS IN AS AUTUMN APPROACHES QUICKLY, FROM OFF.
(ENTERING) Who on Gallius are you two?!
Oh, I’m sorry. We were just...
(COMING OVER) Didn’t you hear the siren? You should have left an hour ago! We’re in lockdown.
We definitely didn’t hear a siren.
I don’t have time to escort you out. (CLIMBS IN) Stay with me for now. When I’ve done what I need to do, I’1l take you back to your habitation zone.
Our habitation zone... yes.
CLOSES THE CANOPY. CROSS TO:
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 15
10. MONOPOD CAPSULE [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: AUTUMN IS OPERATING VARIOUS ON-SCREEN BUTTONS. BEEP BEEP.
You’re lucky I found you and not the Custodians.
THE POD POWERS UP.
Astronomy is on the outskirts. I need to get there fast, so I’ll be using zero inertia. You might want to hang on.
Of course. — You said there was a ‘lockdown’? Is there an emergency of some sort?
Next you’1ll be saying you don’t know about the return.
Return? Return of — [what]?
FX: AUTUMN PUSHES THE ‘START’ BUTTON IN THE MIDST OF ADRIC’S
ABOVE. THE POD SHOOTS OFF AT HIGH SPEED.
(CAUGHT OFF GUARD) Waaaahh!!!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 16
11. INT. ELEVATOR.
IN MOTION.
Feels like this elevator has been going up for ages. I wonder if it’s ever going to...
HALTS.
. stop.
PINGS TO SIGNAL IT’S REACHED THE CORRECT FLOOR.
The viewing deck is at the top of the base. It’s sure to be crowded. But we should still be able to get a good — [view]
OPEN. SILENCE BEYOND.
Oh.
Crowded, did you say?
12. INT. VIEWING DECK. [CONTINUOUS]
GLASS-DOMED AREA. ELEVATOR DOORS CLOSE BEHIND.
(CALLING) Excuse me, folks, but can we get to the front?
Very droll.
Must be the off-season. (AS THEY APPROACH THE GLASS) Great view, though!
Each of those domes is a Hub. The atmosphere here is thin and quite toxic, so they’re connected by a network of underground tunnels.
Which dome are Adric and Nyssa going to?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
That one, I think. On the very edge.
That’s the biggest of the lot.
Page 17
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 18
13. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
BEEPS SUBTLY.
What’s that?
An entry alarm. Unauthorised personnel on the viewing deck. Honestly, you’d think we sounded that siren for fun. (HEADS FOR EXIT) I’1ll take a couple of Custodians and check it out.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 19
14. INT. VIEWING DECK.
WANDERS ACROSS THE FLOOR.
Hey, look out there! What a spaceship!
THE DOCTOR JOINS HER.
Impressive indeed. It’s taking up the entire spaceport.
It’s huge!
It’s an advanced design. It even has... (STOPS HIMSELF) Oh dear.
What?
I think I may have miscalculated...
You mean it’s closer than it looks and actually really tiny.
No... (LOOKING AROUND) What I need is.. Ah, yes. An information terminal.
HE HURRIES TO THE TERMINAL.
What’s wrong?
That ship is fitted with a very special propulsion system. The engine ducts give it away. It’s a Leap Drive.
What’s a ‘Leap Drive’?
One that can move a ship across vast distances in an instant. It’s the first truly intergalactic drive system. It’s what allows humanity to leave the Milky Way. Now... here we are.
HE TAPS A KEY.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 20
(DISTORT, PRESENTING) Ladies and gentlemen, humans and visiting others. — Welcome to Gallius Ultima. The launch platform for
the greatest feat in the history of space exploration. Travel beyond our galaxy.
A MUSICAL FLOURISH.
I thought you said we were a long time before that?
(EMBARRASSED) As I said, a miscalculation. Only by a hundred years or so.
IN B/G, COMPUTER SHOWS THE LAUNCH OF THE KEPLER.
(D) One month ago, the Explorer-class ship Johannes Kepler left Gallius U, en route to the Large Magellanic Cloud. Its crew charged with an historic mission.
MUSICAL FLOURISH.
That confirms it. This is a crucial time for humanity’s development. I try to avoid these.
OPENS BEHIND...
We should go.
EXITS ELEVATOR, WITH TWO CUSTODIANS.
You’11l go alright. With us. — Custodians: cover them!
RAISE THEIR GUNS.
Oh well done, Doctor.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 21
15. INT. MONORAIL TERMINUS.
POD GLIDES IN AND HALTS. CANOPY OPENS. AUTUMN, ADRIC AND NYSSA GET OUT.
That was fast.
(SHAKEN) It was... wasn’t it?
This way.
HURRIES UP A RAMP. ADRIC AND NYSSA FOLLOW, INTO:
16. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB. [CONTINUOUS]
ROOM. INSTRUMENTS TICKING OVER. AUTUMN, ADRIC AND NYSSA ENTER.
Well, here it is. The Astronomy Hub.
It’s very quiet.
Where is everyone?
(APPROACHING AN INSTRUMENT PANEL) It’s almost completely automated. — One moment, please.
PRESSES A SWITCH. COMMS CHANNEL OPENS.
(INTO MIC) Astronomy to Control.
(DISTORT) Go ahead, Autumn.
I’ve arrived, mother. Can you feed the Kepler's telemetry through to me?
(D) It’s being done.
BEEPS ACROSS A SCREEN.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 22
I’ve got it. Realigning now. Keep watching your screens. Astronomy out.
CHANNEL CLOSED. AUTUMN OPERATES FURTHER CONTROLS.
What are you doing? What’s the Kepler?
Where have you been? The Johannes Kepler.
We’re new to... here.
You must be new to life. The Kepler left for the Large Magellanic Cloud a month ago.
A month ago? (TO NYSSA, SOTTO) But the Doctor said...
(SOTTO) He must have miscalculated.
We lost contact. We were prepping the Carl Sagan for a rescue mission. But a few hours ago — sorry, could you step away from those canisters?
(STEPPING AWAY) Sorry. What’s in them?
Liquid nitrogen. For the probe launches. — So yes, a few hours ago the Kepler turned up on the detectors.
That’s good, isn’t it?
Of course. But we’ve not been able to make contact with them. So I’m realigning our orbital telescope to get a look at the ship. And... (MORE BUTTONS) I’m nearly there.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
17. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
OPENS. THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN ARE
(ENTERING) Hey! Quit shoving!
(ENTERING) Calm, Tegan.
Who are these two?
Found them on the Viewing Deck.
IN.
Page 23
I don’t have time to deal with unauthorised tourists! Put
in the detention hub.
Now hang on a minute...
STATIC FROM MAIN SCREEN AS IMAGE RESOLVES.
Controller! We’re getting an image on the main screen.
The Kepler. At last.
FADES.
GASPS AROUND THE ROOM
Good Gods.
What’s happened to them?
them
MOVES TO A COMPUTER SCREEN & BEGINS TAPPING. BEEP BEEP.
(SOTTO) That looks like the ship we saw on the information
terminal.
(SOTTO) Or parts of it. It’s badly damaged.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 24
THE COMPUTER SCREEN DISPLAYS THE READOUT ASSESSMENT ON THE KEPLER.
They’ve lost the cargo section, and at least two explorer modules. There’s damage all along the starboard side.
What could have done this?
There are strong stellar winds in the L.M.C.
Stellar winds didn’t do that.
Custodians — take these “tourists” away.
Please! That damage was deliberate!
Wait.
APPROACHES THE DOCTOR.
What do you know about what’s happened to our ship?
I’ve seen the effect of stellar winds. That isn’t it. Your has come under attack.
From whom?
Well now. That’s the question.
ship
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 25
18. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB.
TAPS CONTROLS.
Beginning a thermographic and spectrographic sweep of the Kepler...
BEGINS.
I’m Autumn, by the way. Autumn Tace. Who are you?
Adric.
Nyssa. Are you in charge here? You’re very young.
I’m the director of Astronomy. My mother is the base Controller.
That lady we heard.
I worked for my position. As it happens, I’m a prodigy!
ALARM ON AN INSTRUMENT PANEL.
The scan’s finished.
PRESSES BUTTONS.
That’s odd. That’s very... Oh.
What?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 26
19. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
THE DOCTOR IS OPERATING A COMPUTER SCREEN, ENLARGING VARIOUS SECTIONS ON A SCHEMATIC OF THE KEPLER.
Look. There’s explosive damage at key points, including the Leap Drive - see here? (A BEEP) - exactly where the tharian
power cells are fitted.
How do you know about the Leap Drive? That’s classified.
I know everything there is to know about Leap Drives. More to the point, so did whoever attacked the Johannes Kepler - this damage was targeted. Not stellar winds.
But if it’s deliberate, that means there’s a hostile force within the L.M.C.
Very probably.
CHANNEL PINGS OPEN.
(DISTORT) Astronomy to Control.
Autumn. What is it?
(D) Mother, I just completed a scan of the ship. It shows a spike in the engine core.
What?
A SUDDEN BEEP BEEP FROM THE DOCTOR'S TERMINAL.
She’s right. They’ve just fired up their ion drive.
(D) I don’t see how. The thermograph also shows no life signs anywhere on the Kepler. I’ve swept the ship from bow to stern. There’‘s nobody aboard.
But someone must be flying it.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 27
Unless it’s been pre-programmed.
ALARM. THE TERMINAL BRINGS UP THE FLIGHT PATH.
Telemetry shows the Kepler is accelerating. Speed at one-eighth luminal and climbing. Her engines are at critical tolerance.
Looks like the Kepler is on a return course to this planet. Presumably to its point of origin — this base.
What’s your point?
Speed one-quarter luminal and climbing.
Their speed is increasing exponentially. They don’t intend to slow down.
But if they don’t slow down... they’1l crash.
General — confirm the Kepler's destination!
FRANTICALLY TAPS AWAY AT THE COMPUTER.
Predicted landing point is... this base.
Stranger. Who are you?
Introductions later. What matters is that whoever attacked your ship is now using it as a weapon against you!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 28
20. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB.
TAPS KEYS. DATA READ-OUT.
Yes. On its current trajectory, the Kepler will land on top of us. Travelling at almost the speed of light.
You should evacuate!
There’s no time.
‘On its current trajectory’...
What?
There might be a way to stop this. (BEAT) Just how big is this space telescope of yours?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 29
21. j%§INT. CONTROL SUITE.
Can’t you shoot it down?
We’ve no weaponry big enough.
We have to find some way to stop it.
ALARM SOUNDS.
What’s that?
The telescope is moving out of orbit.
HITS A SWITCH.
(INTO MIC) Autumn. What’s happening with the telescope?
(D) It’s alright, mother...
22. INT. ASTRONOMY SECTION. [CONTINUOUS]
WORKING CONTROLS.
My friend here had an idea.
(D) What friend?
Hello! Yes, I just had the thought that if we used the telescope...
(D) Who is this?
I’m Adric.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 30
23. INT. CONTROL SUITE. [CONTINUOUS]
Of course. The telescope! Bright lad.
Another of your friends?
(INTO MIC) Adric, it’s the Doctor. Is Nyssa with you?
(D) Here, Doctor!
How many of you are there?
(IGNORING HER) Adric, I take it you’re moving the telescope into the Kepler’s path?
(D) Autumn is.
Good thinking!
How does that help?
The Gallius Deep Space Telescope is the size of a house, Tegan.
It’s still only one-fiftieth the size of the Kepler. Not nearly big enough to stop it.
It doesn’t have to stop it. Just deflect it from its flight path.
Could it do that?
Even a glancing blow might be enough.
(D) Doctor — there’s a problem!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 31
24. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB. [CONTINUOUS]
ALARMS.
Oh, no...!
(D) What’s wrong?
(CALLING) The fail-safes are cutting in!
The computer is predicting the crash. It’s stopping us moving
the telescope into the Kepler's path!
25. INT. CONTROL SUITE. [CONTINUOUS]
Those fail-safes are meant to save lives. Instead they could kill us all...
There is a way, if they switch off the navigation computer and enter the co-ordinates manually.
We’re talking about three-dimensional positioning in zero gravity, and we’ve got minutes. Those calculations need a computer!
Or someone who’s very good with sums. (INTO MIC) Adric, did you hear that?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
26. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB. [CONTINUOUS]
I heard.
Can you do it?
I suppose...
The Doctor thinks you can.
BEAT.
Page 32
(DETERMINED) I’1l need the exact co-ordinates of the ship and the telescope before you shut down the computer.
Let’s do it.
TAPS CONTROLS. DATA ON SCREEN.
Co-ordinates are on screen.
There. Alpha, beta and gamma axes for the Kepler and for the
telescope.
Shutting off navigation computer... now.
POWERS DOWN.
Okay. Got it. (TO SELF, CALCULATING) Axis to triangulation... alpha to alpha, beta to beta,
allowing for transposed gravitational effect...
I input the code?
There.
RAPIDLY INPUTS CODE ON A KEYBOARD.
axis
gamma to gamma...
Autumn,
where do
The telescope array is receiving the repositioning code...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
Code complete!
The telescope is moving.
Well done, Adric.
Let’s hope I got my sums right...
Page 33
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 34
27. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
(D) Confirmed. The telescope is on course towards the Kepler.
Kepler’s speed is now one half-luminal. Time to intercept — twenty seconds.
If your friend’s calculations are out by just one degree, Doctovr...
Have faith, Controller.
Fifteen seconds...
28. EXT. SPACE.
THE KEPLER SHOOTS BY AT HALF THE SPEED OF LIGHT.
IT HITS THE GALLIAN TELESCOPE. AN EXPLOSION. SHIP’S ENGINES
AS IT’S KNOCKED OFF-COURSE.
29. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
Impact!
A CHEER GOES UP
Adric did it?
He certainly did. What’s the course change?
Checking now... (TAPS KEYS) Course deviation... six degrees! Impact zone... fifteen miles west of this location. The Saurian [‘SORE-ian’] desert!
(RELIEVED) Well done the boy.
Very well done.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 35
The Kepler is entering the atmosphere!
30. EXT. DESERT.
THE KEPLER SCREAMS DOWN FROM THE CLOUDS AND CRASHES, SLEWING AND TEARING A GOUGE IN ROCK AND DIRT.
31. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
ARE FELT FROM THE CRASH. THEY FADE.
Strewth. Did you feel that?
And that was from fifteen miles away.
Imagine if that had landed on top of us.
I'd rather not.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 36
32. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB.
AS IN THE CONTROL SUITE, TREMORS SUBSIDING.
We did it!
You did it! Adric, that was brilliant! I could... no, actually, I will! (SHE HUGS HIM)
Woah, steady on!
RELEASES ADRIC.
Three-dimensional spatial geometry, in seconds! I’ve never seen anything like it. So much for my being a prodigy.
It was quite brilliant, Adric. You won’t mind if I don’t hug you?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 37
33. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
And now, would you two like to tell me who you are?
I’m the Doctor and this is Tegan. And what we’re doing here, well...
You know about the Leap Drive. A highly classified secret.
Yes. I can explain that...
You’re with the Earth Science Agency, aren’t you?
Are we?
(QUICKLY) That’s classified.
Sorry. Of course. Totally understood. We have to be discreet. But... thank you. I’m glad the E.S.A. sent you.
The ee eSsS...?
Don’t worry. If anyone asks, you were never here.
Well, now that’s all clear.. I’d like to find out what went wrong with your ship. Investigate the wreckage.
General Fell, the Doctor will be joining the crash response.
Are you sure, Controller?
Quite sure.
KALA AND FELL MOVE AWAY.
(TO DOCTOR) You’re getting heavily involved for someone who wanted to skedaddle half an hour ago.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 38
That was then. There’s something not right.
You’re telling me.
Not just the crash. This whole thing shouldn’t be happening.
What do you mean?
History records the first L.M.C. mission as a resounding success. There was no disaster, no crash... Something is interfering with the established timeline.
MUSIC SEGUE.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 39
34. EXT. JOHANNES KEPLER CRASH SITE.
THE SMOULDERING WRECK OF THE HUGE SPACECRAFT IS STREWN ALL AROUND.
THE DOCTOR, TEGAN, FELL AND A GROUP OF RESCUERS APPROACH.
ARE IN RESPIRATOR MASKS.
(MASK DISTORT) Even as a wreck, this thing’s impressive.
(D) The main fuselage is mostly intact. We should find a way
in.
(D) Over there. There’s a cargo hatch.
35. INT. JOHANNES KEPLER: CARGO HOLD.

DOCTOR: I know everything there is to know about Leap Drives. More to the point, so did whoever attacked the Johannes Kepler - this damage was targeted. Not stellar winds.

KALA: Autumn. What is it?
AUTUMN: (D) Mother, I just completed a scan of the ship. It shows a spike in the engine core.
KALA: What?
KALA: A SUDDEN BEEP BEEP FROM THE DOCTOR'S TERMINAL.
DOCTOR: She’s right. They’ve just fired up their ion drive.
AUTUMN: (D) I don’t see how. The thermograph also shows no life signs anywhere on the Kepler. I’ve swept the ship from bow to stern. There’‘s nobody aboard.

DOCTOR: Unless it’s been pre-programmed.
INSTRUMENT: ALARM. THE TERMINAL BRINGS UP THE FLIGHT PATH.

DOCTOR: Looks like the Kepler is on a return course to this planet. Presumably to its point of origin — this base.
KALA: What’s your point?
OPERATOR: Speed one-quarter luminal and climbing.

DOCTOR: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 28
AUTUMN: TAPS KEYS. DATA READ-OUT.

AUTUMN: What?

ADRIC: 21. j%§INT. CONTROL SUITE.

ADRIC: I’m Adric.

ADRIC: (D) Autumn is.
DOCTOR: Good thinking!

CROSS TO: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
ADRIC: I heard.
AUTUMN: Can you do it?
ADRIC: I suppose...

NYSSA: BEAT.

AUTUMN: axis

AUTUMN: Autumn,
AUTUMN: where do

DOCTOR: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 39

FELL: SPACIOUS, ECHOING METAL-WALLED AREA. A HATCH OPENS. THE DOCTOR, TEGAN, FELL AND THE RESCUE PARTY ENTER.
FELL: (REMOVING MASK) You can remove your masks in here.

ALL: CLICK ON THEIR GLOVE TORCHES.

DOCTOR: (WALKING FORWARD ) Interesting...

DOCTOR: I wouldn’t touch it, General.
DOCTOR: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 40
TEGAN: Seen anything like this before, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Not quite, no.

TEGAN: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 41

TEGAN: What?

FELL: APPROACHES.

FELL: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 43

DOCTOR: Splendid.

TEGAN: Then you’1l need me to look after you, won’t you?

ADRIC: I won’t be much help with that.
AUTUMN: You’1ll be much safer here, Adric.

ITS: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 46

able

Do as I tell you. Go.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 60
62. INT. CORRIDOR. [CONTINUOUS]
OPENS. KALA EXITS. DOOR CLOSES. AUTUMN, NYSSA AND ADRIC
KALA.
Mother, are you alright?
You were very brave, Controller.
I don’t understand. Someone kills our people... then takes over their bodies? Why?
What matters for now is to keep everyone else safe.
You’re right.
HITS A WALL SWITCH.
(HER VOICE REVERBERATES ON SPEAKERS) This is Controller Tace. Due to an emergency, all operatives in the Science Hub will evacuate immediately. Repeat, evacuate!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 61
63. INT. CARL SAGAN — BRIDGE.
IN FLIGHT. CREW BUSY. DETECTORS PINGING IN BACKGROUND.
This is the plan. We follow the intended route of the Johannes Kepler, while scanning for ship residue.
And, what, hope we run into the same trouble the Kepler did?
For the last time, Doctor: the Kepler was a scientific mission. Ours is military. I told you, I’ve got a brigade of Custodians on board.
Custodians of what?
Good order.
Soldiers, Tegan. General — do we have communications with Gallius U?

No. Same as the Kepler, we lost comms when we entered the cloud. It’s expected, we had the same issue with the unmanned probes we’d sent in previously. But the Kepler was supposed to launch a message packet out of the cloud with updates. That didn’t happen.
When was the first packet due?
No later than twelve hours after arrival.
Then whatever happened to the Kepler, it happened within the first twelve hours.
Did any of your previous unmanned probes have difficulties?
There were three probe missions. We lost one. Although that wasn’t a surprise.
Why not?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 62
The first two didn’t come far into the cloud. But the third went into the Tarantula Nebula.
Tarantula. Sounds spooky.
The Tarantula Nebula, or 30 Derondus, is full of new stars. Intense radiation and stellar winds. Inhospitable, to say the least.
PING AN ALERT.
What’s that?

Detector alert. Let’s see.. (TAPS CONTROLS) Several objects drifting on a bearing of one-eight-eight. At a distance of point-two K.P.C. (TO CREW) Set a new course, Pilot. Bearing one-eight-eight, four luminals.
SURGE.
We might have got lucky.
‘Lucky’. I wonder.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 63
64. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
SOUNDING. OPERATORS BUSY AT WORKSTATIONS AS KALA, AUTUMN, ADRIC AND NYSSA RUN IN.
(ENTERING) Crewman, seal bulkhead six!
Ma’am!
HITS A SWITCH THAT RESPONDS WITH AN EMPHATIC TONE.
At least now those things are contained to the Science Hub.
That’s what they seem to want, though.
Maybe they don’t want us to see what they’re doing.
Then they’re out of luck. I can bring up vision from the examination room...
Do it.
HITS A SWITCH. IMAGE BLIPS ON.
The cheeky...!
They’re accessing the computers!
Shut off network access in the Science Hub!
I’1l do it. (PRESSES SWITCHES - UNHELPFUL SULLEN BEEP) No response. They’ve overridden the system!
What can they do with computer access?
Study our records, base layout, personnel data...
He’s gone.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 64
What? Who’s gone?
Renn. He isn’t in the examination room.
You’re right... I’l1l bring up the corridors.
BLIP. IMAGE CHANGES.
Good grief.
There’s coral everywhere. It’s spread from the examination room.
Wait! There’s Renn. In corridor 4M.
Enlarging. (A BEEP. THE IMAGE CHANGES) What’s he doing?
Just standing there, it seems. Watching the coral.
What are they up to?
I assume at some point they’re going to come out of the Science Hub.
Couldn’t your Custodians deal with them?
You saw what happened to the Custodian in the examination room. And I don’t have many — the main garrison left with General Fell.
The red coral is the key to it all. We need an inert sample for analysis.
We can’t go back to the Science Hub!
We don’t have to. There’s still plenty on the Kepler.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 65
The Kepler. Of course. I’1ll send a robot over.
No. We know they’re vulnerable to the coral. I’1ll go and recover a sample myself.
We’1ll all go. You, me and Adric.
You've seen how dangerous that stuff is, Autumn. I don’t think we should go near it.
Have you got a better idea, Adric?
Well... (HE DOESN'T; RESIGNED) Oh, alright then!
While you’re doing that, I’ll send a distress signal to Earth Control, requesting urgent military assistance.
KEYS IN A SEQUENCE OF BUTTONS.
They should respond — [quickly]
RESPONSE FROM THE INSTRUMENTS.
No. Oh no.
What’s wrong?
Our communications are jammed.
TRIES AGAIN. SAME RESPONSE.
They’ve cut us off. We’re on our own.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 66
65. INT. CARL SAGAN: BRIDGE.
POWER DOWN.
We’ve arrived. Let’s see what’s out there. Open view screen!
SCREEN OPENS.
Gods. This is it.
Definitely parts of the Kepler.
Hey, see in the middle there? That piece looks almost intact.
You’re right. That’s one of the explorer modules. It must have become detached.
Could there be people still alive on there?
Local radiation makes a scan impossible. But there could be life support. I’1ll take a boarding party and investigate.
I’1l come with you.
And me!
This isn’t a pleasure trip. But.. Very well. Get suited up.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 67
66. INT. JOHANNES KEPLER: CARGO HOLD.
OPENS. NYSSA, AUTUMN AND ADRIC ENTER AND ACTIVATE GLOVE TORCHES.
(MASK DISTORT) There’s coral everywhere.
(D) I’d keep your masks on, just in case. And before you go any
further, let me run a scan. Make sure it’s inert.
(D) Go ahead.
STEPS FORWARD, ACTIVATES A HANDHELD SCANNER.
(D) Looks good. Where do you want to collect your sample?
(D) From the wall here is as good as any.
(D) I’1l scan that a little deeper. To the atomic level.
APPLIES THE BUZZING SCANNER CLOSE TO THE CORAL.
(D) I’ll only need a small sample. I’11 take it back for — [analysis]
THE CORAL CRACKS.
(D) It’s active!
(D) We know what comes next — the gas.
THE CORAL ALL AROUND THEM FRACTURES, SPLITS, TRANFORMING TO
ENERGISED GAS.
(D) Get out! Run!
THEY RUN FOR THE HATCH AND THROW THEMSELVES OUT. CROSS TO:
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 68
67. EXT. CRASH SITE. [CONTINUOUS]
NYSSA, ADRIC AND AUTUMN THROW THEMSELVES FROM THE HATCH,
IT / SEALING IT BEHIND THEM.
ADRIC, AUTUMN AND NYSSA: (MASK DISTORT) (HITTING THE GROUND) Oof!
THE GAS HISSES WITHIN THE HOLD.
(D) It’s like it reacted to something.
(D) The Doctor and Tegan were in there before. Nothing happened then.
(D) They didn’t run a scan.
(D) That’s what happened in the examination room! Everything was fine until the robot ran its scan.
(D) It’s organic... I suppose it could have reacted to the electromagnetic radiation from the scanner. Well, we might not have got our sample, but we learned something. Come on, let’s get back.
THEY HURRY OFF.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 69
68. INT. CARL SAGAN: AIRLOCK.
FELL, THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN, TOGETHER WITH A SECURITY PARTY OF
CUSTODIANS HEFTING BLASTERS.
A WALL CONTROL PINGS.
Alright. We’ve docked, and there’s atmosphere in there. Custodians will lead the way - keep your blasters primed and
ready to fire. (THEY DO SO.) Doctor, Tegan, stay close to me.
Lead on.
69. EXPLORER MODULE: AIRLOCK CORRIDOR.
WALLS AND FLOORS. EERILY QUIET.
A HEAVY AIRLOCK UNSEALS AND OPENS. THE DOCTOR, TEGAN, FELL AND
ARMED CUSTODIANS ENTER.
Quiet as the...
(STOPPING HIM) Doctor.
Yes. Well, it’s quiet.
(POINTING) More of that red coral. On the wall, see?
Until we know its properties, we should keep clear.
We’1ll conduct a systematic search. Starting in the — [rear]
A CLANG OF MOVEMENT FROM THE DARK. CUSTODIANS RAISE THEIR GUNS.
Who’s there?!
BEAT.
Whoever it is, it seems they’re shy.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 70
(SOTTO) If they won’t come to us, we’ll go to them. Forward, Slowly.
THEY START FORWARD.
Hey. There’s a light down there.
Oh yes... A glow.
Let’s take a closer look.
70. INT. KEPLER SECTION: CORRIDOR.
A STAR MAN PORTAL IS ACROSS THE CORRIDOR. A GLOWING ORGANIC OPENING. FAINT HUM OF POWER.
elements.character: THE GROUP MOVES OFF. CROSS TO

elements.text: DOCTOR, TEGAN, FELL AND CUSTODIANS APPROACH.
elements.character: THE GROUP MOVES OFF. CROSS TO

elements.text: What in the name of... ?
Red coral again. It’s blocking the corridor. Some kind of barricade?
Rather flimsy for a barricade. Coral round the outside, but in the middle... thin, like a membrane.
What’s making it glow?
It’s energised in some way.
MOVES FORWARD.
Careful, Doctor...!
RUSHES IN FROM BEHIND THEM. BEDRAGGLED, WEAK.
No! Stay back!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 71
RAISE THEIR GUNS.
Who the dreck are you?! Stand still or we’1ll shoot!
You must keep away from the portal! Please. It’s not safe!
We should do as he says.
He’s alien, Doctor. Look at his eyes!
Look at his clothes - they’re in rags. He’s in a bad way.
(TO NOMAR) Who are you? What have you done to this ship and its crew?
None of this is my doing. I’m sorry, but.. all your people were killed.
What?!
THE PORTAL SURGES WITH POWER.
What’s happening?
The ‘portal’, as our friend here called it, seems to be powering up.
We should get away! It’s opening.
Doctor, someone’s coming through!
THE SHIMMERING PRESENCE OF A STAR MAN MOVES TOWARDS US FROM THE
SIDE OF THE PORTAL.
I see them. (PEERS) Is that a man? It has a man’s shape... but there’s nothing to it. Full of... lights?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 72
(FEARFUL) They are the Star Men.
Now you mention it, he does look like he’s made of stars.
STEPS IN THROUGH THE PORTAL. HE — LIKE ALL STAR MEN — HAS A SHIMMERING PRESENCE, WHICH RESONATES AS HE MOVES.
(WARY) Hello... Who are you?
NO REPLY.
Can it hear us?
(ANGER) It hears you. This is the murderer of your people.
Is that right? Did you kill the crew of this ship?
Perhaps if we could calm down...
They died as you will all die. (TO TEGAN) You. The female.
I do have a name, as it happens. It’s — (GRABBED) Aah!
You will come with me.
HE DRAGS HER INTO THE PORTAL.
Doctor, help!
(TO ROVUS) Please, leave my friend alone!
(ENTERING THE PORTAL AND FADING) Doctor...!!!
Custodians!
No, don’t shoot! You might hit [Tegan! ]
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 73
THE PORTAL’S POWER FADES AWAY AS THE CUSTODIANS OPEN FIRE,
APART THE PORTAL MEMBRANE, SHATTERING THE CORAL SURROUND.
They’ve gone. Stop shooting!!
Cease fire!
STOPS.
You idiots, you’ve destroyed the portal! How can we get Tegan
back now!?
Your friend is lost.
Do you know where that portal leads?!
To the world of the Star Men. Within the nebula.
THE CORAL AROUND THEM CRACKS AND SPLITS. TRANSFORMS TO GAS.
That coral, it’s cracking. — Is that gas?
(MOVING AWAY) The red cloud! (RUNNING) Run or you will die!
You heard him! Run!
THEY RUN. THE GAS HISSES AND FOLLOWS THEM.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 74
71. %INT. EXPLORER MODULE: AIRLOCK CORRIDOR.
DOCTOR, FELL, NOMAR AND CUSTODIANS RUN IN. THE GAS HISSING
US IN BACKGROUND.
Into the airlock, all of you! Quickly!
The alien, too?
We can’t leave him here to die. Everybody in!
THEY ENTER THE AIRLOCK, WHICH SLAMS SHUT. CROSS TO:
72. INT. CARL SAGAN: AIRLOCK.
CLOSES. FELL ACTIVATES A WALL COMMUNICATOR.
(INTO MIC) Pilot — this is the General. Get us away from here!
LATER, A HEAVY CLUNK AS THE SAGAN DISENGAGES. ENGINES
AS IT PULLS AWAY.
(RELIEF) Just in time.
Custodians, watch that alien!
I mean you no harm.
Thank you for trying to warn us. I’m the Doctor, by the way.
I am Nomar, of the Vileri. Please... do you have any food?
Never mind food. You’ve got questions to answer.
As part of a civilised conversation, General. Yes, Nomar, we have food. Then I’d like to know more about these ‘Star Men’. And where they’ve taken Tegan.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 75
73. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
The coral was activated by the scan?
It must react to a power source. Though it’s an organism in its own right, it might possibly controlled by others.
In the same way Renn and the other dead are being controlled.
What’s Renn doing now?
He’s still in that corridor. The coral is growing up the walls there. He watches it. Like he’s guarding it.
Are they still jamming our communications?
Yes.
We have to get help. We have to get a message out.
How?
There might be a way.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 76
74. INT. CARL SAGAN: BRIDGE.
EATING FROM A BOWL.
(EATING) Thank you. This is good. I have not eaten in three days...
You can talk while you’re eating.
Nomar. Your people, the Vileri. Do they come from this galaxy?
We are an old people, and proud.
I’ve not heard of a race like these ‘Star Men’ before. Their appearance is quite unique.
Their true name, the name of their species, is the Keltin. They came to conquer my world. They numbered few, no more than a score.
As few as that?
They were all-powerful. They slaughtered many of my people. Others they took as prisoners — to work as slaves in their mines, or in their great Citadel. That is where I served them. Until my escape.
Where is this Citadel of theirs?
On a planetoid. A rock they have occupied. In the nebula from which they appeared. The nebula of the stars.
The Tarantula Nebula.
I do not know that name.
They come from that hell hole?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 77
That must be where they’ve taken Tegan. General — will you help me get her back?
More than that. We’re going on the attack.
What?
You heard him. There aren’t many of these ‘Star Men’. We’1l go to their world alright. And we’ll wipe them off the face of it before they can attack anyone again.
You saw what they did to the Kepler!
The Kepler was a civilian research mission. We’re trained for this.
This ‘Kepler’. Was it a ship like this?
Yes.
It was engulfed in the red cloud.
Red cloud? That’s what you called the gas that came from the coral.
The red rock. The red cloud. They are controlled by the Star Men. I think... I think they are the essence of the Star Men.
How interesting. What do you mean by — [that]?
Nomar. If we go to the nebula, could you lead us to this planetoid?
I could. Many of my people are enslaved there still.
You guide us there, we’ll take care of the Star Men. We’1ll free your people. And get Tegan back for you, Doctor.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 78
WALKS AWAY.
(MOVING AWAY) Set course for the Tarantula Nebula!
Nomar. Do you really think the General can defeat the Star Men?
I will take any chance to free my people. However small.
But do you think the Star Men can be beaten?
BEAT.
No.
Oh, Tegan...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 79
75. INT. DETENTION CHAMBER.
A HIGH-CEILINGED MARBLE CHAMBER.
Who are you? What are you?
I am Rovus. Imperator [imper-RA-tor] of the Keltin, known to some as the Star Men.
You don’t look much like a man. More like a walking hole in the air.
You lack the ability to comprehend a life form that does not correspond to your experience.
(SOTTO) I know a hole when I see it. (ALOUD) Where is this place?
You are in a detention chamber within our Citadel. We are many light years from your friends. But they will be coming to rescue you. They have Nomar to show them the way.
They’re coming??
I hope so. That’s why I took you. As bait.
Bait?! — Oh, no..!
We are ready for them, and shall destroy them. Entirely.
You don’t need to do that!
HE STRIDES TO THE EXIT.
You will remain here.
Listen to me!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 80
You live only so long as you are useful to us.
EXITS. A DOOR SLAMS DOWN.
RUNS TO THE DOOR, HAMMERS ON IT.
Oi! Come back! .. (STOPS HAMMERING) Rabbits.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 81
76. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
Mother — I think I know how we can beat the jamming.
I’m listening, Autumn.

By using our satellites! — Think about it. The satellites transmit telemetry data. That’s a form of communication. I can reconfigure the satellite data net to receive the distress message and retransmit it to Earth Control. Bypassing the comms system.
That could work.
It’s rather clever. Brilliant, in fact.
Thank you, Adric.
Yes, but can you do it from here?
From the Central Power Room. It’s not far.
Do it. But be careful, and stay in touch.
I’1l come with you.
(BRIGHTLY) Thanks. Let’s go.
Good luck.
ADRIC AND AUTUMN EXIT.
We should check the Science Hub.
BLIP. IMAGE ON SCREEN.
That’s odd. The other dead crewmen have joined Renn in that corridor.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 82
What are they up to?
It might be clearer once one or two of them move out of the way. There isn’t another view unfortunately. Ah, and as I say that, there you go... Oh. What is that, across the corridor? A barricade?
Strange. Looks like they’ve spun some kind of organic material across the middle.
It doesn’t look like coral. More like...
Like skin.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 83
77. INT. CARL SAGAN: BRIDGE.
THE FRONT VIEWSCREEN OPENS.
There it is. The Tarantula Nebula.
The brightest star-forming region anywhere in this corner of the universe. It’s quite a sight.
Very dangerous. The Vileri would not come here through choice.
I don’t blame you. The stars give off fierce radiation, and the stellar winds heat some areas to millions of degrees.
This is an Explorer-class ship. It’s up to the job. [TO THE
] Pilot, divert power to the forward shields.
Yes, General.
WE HEAR THE FORWARD SHIELDS POWERING UP.
Nomar, you said the planetoid is near to the central star
cluster?
It is.
That’s cluster R-one-thirty-six. We’ll head there, and you can guide us as we get closer. (TO CREW) All engines full ahead! THE ENGINES SURGE.
(TO SELF) Brave heart, Tegan. We’re on our way.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 84
78. INT. CORRIDOR.
ADRIC AND AUTUMN APPROACH AND STOP.
Is this it?
Yes, this is the power room.
OPERATES A KEYPAD. DOOR OPENS. CROSS TO:
79. INT. POWER ROOM. [CONTINUOUS]
ADRIC AND AUTUMN HALT ON THE THRESHOLD.
Woah! Red coral!
Keep away from it.
There are marks on the wall by the air vents. It must have come
in as a gas and solidified.
Where are the controls we need?
It’s that bank of switches over there.
They’re clear. (CROSSES TO INSTRUMENTS) We can still do this.
REMAINS WHERE SHE IS.
Adric, come back. This stuff is deadly.
All the more reason to get that message out before it spreads further.
THE CORAL CRACKS AND SPLITS. FORMING GAS, BEHIND FOLLOWING.
Adric, get out! It’s forming the gas!
Quickly, tell me what to do! What switches?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 85
I’m coming over.
Stay back! There’s no need for both of us to be at risk.
Well, if you’re sure —
Of course I’m sure! Now what do I do?!
It’s the eight red switches. One for each satellite in the net. Go from left to right. But this is important — you have to wait for each one to go green.
Got it. Starting now.
HE PUSHES THE FIRST SWITCH. AFTER A MOMENT, A TONE AS IT TURNS GREEN. THEN THE NEXT.
Come on, come on...
THE GAS HISSES AND SWIRLS. CROSS TO:
80. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
Autumn and Adric should be in the power room now. I’1l put it on screen.
ACTIVATES THE SCREEN. WE HEAR THE CRACKING CORAL, THE
GAS.
(SHOCKED) Adric!
81. INT. POWER ROOM. [CONTINUOUS]
A GREEN LIGHT TONE.
Three more to go. It takes an age for those green lights to come on!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 86
THE GAS CLOSES ON ADRIC.
Adric, there’s no time! The gas is heading your way. Run!
I’m nearly there! Ten seconds!
You don’t have ten seconds!
HE HITS A SWITCH. AND WAITS.
Oh come on, come on...! (COUGHS, CHOKING, AS THE GAS ENVELOPS HIM)
82. INT. CONTROL SUITE. [CONTINUOUS]
Adric! No!
It’s got him. Just like my Custodian.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
83. INT. POWER ROOM. [CONTINUOUS]
(COUGHING, CHOKING) I can’t... breathe!
(TELEPATHIC — IN ADRIC’S HEAD) You have failed, boy!
What? — Who are you?!
Adric? Who are you talking to?
I heard a voice! A voice in my head! The same voice that was
Ensign Renn!
TELEPATHIC) (CHUCKLES
Get out! Get out of my mind!!!
Page 87
in
(TELEPATHIC) I will destroy your mind, boy — you will belong to
the Star Men!
A RESONATING ENERGY BUILDS UP INSIDE ADRIC’S HEAD — TARGETING
MIND.
(PAINED) No. No..!!!
END OF PART TWO
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 88

EVERYONE: RELEASES THEIR SEAT RESTRAINTS. DOCTOR AND TEGAN STAND AND WALK FORWARD.
FELL: (TO ROOM) Open forward screens!
PANELS: OVER THE VIEWING SCREEN SLIDE AWAY.
TEGAN: Wow.
DOCTOR: It’s even more remarkable close up, isn’t it?

DOCTOR: The Large Magellanic Cloud. Yes, Tegan.

FELL: Maintain detectors at full range, three-sixty-degree sweep.

TEGAN: Great.
TEGAN: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 51
TEGAN: A COMPACT AREA. AUTUMN ENTERS WITH ADRIC AND NYSSA.
AUTUMN: Mother? Is it alright if Adric and Nyssa sit in on the autopsies?
KALA: Do they really want to?

KALA: Take a seat. The surgical robots are preparing the bodies.
KALA: AUTUMN AND NYSSA SIT.
ADRIC: Look, Nyssa - you don’t really need me here, do you?
NYSSA: (CHIDING HIM) Adric...
AUTUMN: Don’t worry. It’s all non-invasive. The surgical robot will scan the body, and the three-dimensional image will come up on this screen. No blood.
ADRIC: (SITTING) Still. All those bodies... it’s creepy.
NYSSA: (TO KALA) I see the bodies are still covered in the coral.
KALA: It’ll be removed as part of the autopsy. The examination room is a controlled environment. If the coral is toxic, we’re safe watching from here. (SHE PRESSES A SPEAKER SWITCH) Robot. You can begin.
SURGICAL ROBOT: (SPEAKER DISTORT) Acknowledged.

CROSS TO: 47. EXAMINATION ROOM. [CONTINUOUS]
SURGICAL ROBOT: The first cadaver is identified as Ensign Caleb Renn. Confirmed zero life signs. The body is partially encased in a red calcareous substance with the appearance of the exoskeleton secreted by certain Terran marine polyps, commonly referred to as ‘coral’. Beginning scan.

ADRIC: His thoughts were strange. Images rather than words. But I saw these Star Men. This base was destroyed! And the Star Men... spreading everywhere, to other worlds. Killing. And they’re going to start here. The Star Men are coming. Lots of them!
ADRIC: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 128
PORTAL: REVERBERATES WITH ENERGY. VEDRIN EMERGES.
VEDRIN: Hear me, Rovus. I have arrived on Gallius Ultima.
ROVUS: Good, Vedrin. More of our people are coming?
VEDRIN: Many more.
VEDRIN: 12 x STAR MEN EMERGE FROM THE PORTAL THROUGH:
ROVUS: Go. Take control of this place. Kill all who resist... These
ROVUS: cadavers are no longer needed. I shall jettison this integrated known as Renn.
ROVUS: RENN AND THE OTHER CADAVERS COLLAPSE TO THE FLOOR.
VEDRIN: Forward, my Star Men!
VEDRIN: VEDRIN AND A DOZEN STAR MEN WALK UP CORRIDOR.
VEDRIN: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 129
KALA: What are those things?!
NYSSA: Aliens. The ones who’ve been behind this all along.
KALA: HITS ALARM. KLAXON SOUNDS.
KALA: (INTO MIC, REVERBERATING FROM NEARBY SPEAKERS) This is the Controller! Emergency! Threat Level One! Repeat: Threat Level One! The base is being invaded! Custodians stand ready! Custodians stand — [ready]
KALA: THE BULKHEAD IS HIT BY AN ENERGY BLAST FROM THE FAR SIDE.
NYSSA: They’re at the bulkhead!
MORE: ENERGY BLASTS. BULKHEAD MELTS, COLLAPSES.
NYSSA: It’s giving way! Kala! Run!
NYSSA: KALA AND NYSSA RUN OFF. VEDRIN AND HIS STAR MEN ENTER THROUGH
BULKHEAD: REMAINS.
VEDRIN: Go. Move through all sections. Kill all who resist.
STAR: MEN MOVE IN ALL DIRECTIONS.
STAR: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 130
GRAVEL: FLOOR, ROCK WALLS. MOANING ATMOSPHERE OF HELIOPAN IS MUTED.
LOM: You’re safe here. The Krail won’t come into the caves.
TEGAN: Thank you for bringing us here. I’m Tegan, by the way.
NOMAR: Nomar.
LOM: I am Lom. You are welcome.
TEGAN: Do you live here?
LOM: As best I can. I am the last of my kind. The others... are dead. This world and everything beyond it is dying.
TEGAN: What is this world?
LOM: You are on the planet Heliopan [HE-lee-oh-pan]. Sent here by the Star Men, no doubt. It is my home. It breaks my heart to see it now.
NOMAR: What happened?
LOM: The Star Men killed it. Bled it dry. As they have bled this universe dry in search of the energy they need.
TEGAN: They did that?
LOM: Look outside and you will see what they did. They are world killers.
LOM: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
LOM: SOUNDS OF BATTLE IN THE BACKGROUND. ROUNDS, INTERSPERSED WITH CUSTODIAN
CUSTODIANS: NYSSA AND KALA RUN IN.
NYSSA: Quickly, Controller. The TARDIS!
KALA: What is that?
NYSSA: Safety!
SHE: TRIES THE DOORS — SHUT.
NYSSA: Only it’s locked!
NYSSA: Page 131
STAR: MEN FIRING ENERGY GUNFIRE AND EXPLOSIONS.
STAR: VEDRIN AND TWO STAR MEN RUN IN. VEDRIN FIRES AN ENERGY SHOT
THAT: EXPLODES IN THE FLOOR.
NYSSA AND KALA: (SURPRISED) Aah!
VEDRIN: Stand still or die. (APPROACHING) What is this?
NYSSA: Nothing. Just... a box.
VEDRIN: SHOVES AT TARDIS DOORS.
VEDRIN: Open it.
NYSSA: I can’t!
VEDRIN: It has power... It is a ship of some kind.
KALA: Really? This is a ship?
VEDRIN: I have it... You are with the Doctor.
VEDRIN: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 132
NYSSA: The Doctor? Never heard of him.
VEDRIN: You lie. (TO STAR MEN) Star Men — we need another portal, here. Fashion one.
VEDRIN: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
VEDRIN: Page 133
DOOR: OPENS. ROVUS ENTERS.
DOCTOR: Ah, Rovus! I was beginning to think
ROVUS: Come with me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: STANDS.
DOCTOR: Are we going anywhere nice?
ROVUS: You will see.
ROVUS: you’d forgotten about me.
ROVUS: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 134
ROVUS: A PORTAL IS HUMMING WITH POWER.
NYSSA: (SOTTO) So now we know. The membranes are portals. That’s how these ‘Star Men’ got here.
KALA: (SOTTO) More to the point — if they can place more of them anywhere they like, we’ll be completely overrun.
VEDRIN: Silence. The Imperator is coming.
ENERGY: BUILDS WITHIN THE PORTAL. AS IT PEAKS, ROVUS EMERGES WITH THE DOCTOR.
NYSSA: DOCTOR!
DOCTOR: Nyssa. Hello!
ROVUS: (GOING TO TARDIS) Vedrin, this box — is this the vessel you spoke of?
VEDRIN: It resists all attempts to force entry. Its energy signature suggests temporal capability, and that it is in dimensional flux.
ROVUS: A vessel fit for a Time Lord. — Eh, Doctor?
DOCTOR: That blue box has nothing to do with me, Rovus.
ROVUS: Don’t try to fool me, Doctor. Open your time machine. Now!
DOCTOR: No, sorry. You’re doing enough damage to the timeline as it is.
ROVUS: Vedrin.
VEDRIN: GRABS HOLD OF NYSSA.
NYSSA: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 135
DOCTOR: Let Nyssa go!
ROVUS: Doctor, you have already lost one of your friends to the Dark... Do you wish to lose another?
ROVUS: A WAVE OF HIS ARM, AND THE PORTAL ADOPTS THE OMINOUS RUMBLE OF A DARK PORTAL.
NYSSA: Doctor, does he mean Tegan? What’s happened to her?
DOCTOR: Try not to worry. We’ll get her back.
NYSSA: Back from where?
ROVUS: This portal is now reset to the Dark. You will open your
ROVUS: machine.
DOCTOR: I can’t give you access to my TARDIS.
ROVUS: Vedrin — throw her in.
NYSSA: (STRUGGLES AS SHE’S LED) No!
DOCTOR: Please! Don’t do this!
VEDRIN: THROWS NYSSA INTO THE PORTAL.
NYSSA: (CRIES OUT, THE CRY STIFLED BY THE PORTAL) No! Doctor...!
DEEP: RESONANCE AS NYSSA DISAPPEARS INTO THE PORTAL.
DOCTOR: Nyssa!
ROVUS: I don’t bluff, Doctor. She’s gone.
ROVUS: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
NYSSA: SCRAMBLES ON THE SHALE-LIKE SURFACE.
NYSSA: Hello? .. Hello, is anyone h- [ere?!] (LOSES HER DOWN THE SLOPE) Waah!
SHE: PICKS HERSELF UP.
NYSSA: Evidently not. Where am I, I wonder...?
NYSSA: A KRAIL LOPES IN, STOPS NEARBY, AND SHRIEKS.
NYSSA: Oh no. I hope you’re not as hungry as you 1ook...
TWO: FURTHER KRAIL APPEAR. SNARLING, SNORTING.
NYSSA: More of them. — Get back! Get back, please...!!!
ALL: THREE KRAIL GIVE A FEARSOME, BLOOD-CURDLING
ALL: END OF PART THREE
ALL: Page 136
ALL: BALANCE,
ALL: SHRIEK.
SLIDES: #221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 137

elements.text: PART FOUR
122. INT. ARRIVALS HUB.
THE PORTAL CHANGES TONE. EASING, NO LONGER THE DARK PORTAL.
Do not imagine that you will see either of your friends again, Doctor. Now open your machine!!
More than ever, Rovus. No.
BEAT.
You are fortunate I need you alive. You will give us access to your machine, Doctor. However many more lives it takes. But first we must secure our grip on this base.
In which case: might I suggest that Controller Tace here is allowed to speak to her people?
For what purpose?
To tell them to surrender.
Doctor!
Kala, you can’t hold out against the Star Men. Trust me.
BEAT.
If it will save lives... yes.
Excellent.
We’ll need to go to the control suite.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 138
Vedrin, bring the Doctor.
(SOTTO) I don’t know whether to thank you or curse you.
(SOTTO) It buys us some time. Enough, I hope, to save your
people... and my friends.
THEY EXIT.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 139
123. INT. LOM’S CAVE.
Heliopan was once a beautiful world, under the heat of three suns.
Three? What happened to the other two?
Reduced to husks by the Keltin.
Then they would do the same in our universe?
We have to — [get back]
(OFF) Help! Help!!!
Who was that?
It sounded like... Is that Nyssa?!
RUNS OUT.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 140
124. EXT. HELIOPAN: SLOPE.
KRAIL CLOSING ON NYSSA, SNARLING.
Keep back! (PICKS UP A SMALL ROCK) I know how to throw, I’ve seen the Doctor do it often enough — (THROWS IT)
A KRAIL, HIT, SHRIEKS IN PAIN. RETREATS.
How’s that?! (PICKS UP ANOTHER)
2 x KRAIL SNARL DEFIANTLY, EDGE CLOSER.
(NEARBY) Nyssa!
Tegan! The Doctor said you’d been sent here — (EFFORT; THROWS
STONE)
SHRIEKS, HIT.
You won’t bowl those things out with stones! — Quick! Up here!
There’s a cave!
Oh, thank goodness!
SCRAMBLES UP THE SLOPE. THE KRAIL SHRIEK IN ANGER.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 141
125. INT. LOM’S CAVE.
ENTERS, FOLLOWED BY BREATHLESS NYSSA.
Come on. You’ll be safe in here. Lom says the Krail don’t come into the caves.
They fear the dark. Soon, they will tire and move away.
Nyssa, this is Lom, and that’s Nomar.
Greetings.
Nyssa’s a friend of mine. We travel together.
Tegan — where are we, exactly?
This might take a while...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 142
126. INT. CORRIDOR.
ADRIC AND AUTUMN RUNNING.
It’s hopeless running, Autumn! The Star Men are everywhere!
We have to find Mother. Tell her everything you learned about them!
KALA’S VOICE COMES OVER TANNOY.
(D) All personnel, this is Controller Tace.
ADRIC AND AUTUMN STOP.
That’s her!
(D) All resistance to the alien presence — to these ‘Star Men’ — will cease.
I don’t believe it!
(DISTORT) Regular personnel will go to their habitats. Custodians will put down their arms. The Star Men are now in command of Gallius U.
CLOSES.
That’s it. We’ve lost!
Your mother might have surrendered, but we don’t have to!
What choice have we got?
It’s not a choice. I’ve seen what they’re planning to do...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 143
127. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
Satisfied, Rovus?
Very good, Controller.
It was the right thing to do, Kala.
The question is: have I saved my people? Or just made it easier for the Star Men to slaughter them?
Vedrin? Prepare the signal. To read, ‘Compatibility confirmed. Bridgehead established.’
At once. (TURNS AND LEAVES)
‘Bridgehead’? I don’t like the sound of that.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 144
128. INT. LOM’S CAVE.
One by one, the galaxies throughout this universe have gone dark. Until now there is just this one corner of light.
So with so few suns remaining here, the Star Men needed to look elsewhere for their...
‘food’?

The Keltin — the Star Men — found a way to tear an opening between universes. Yours was not the first they visited. But it was the first that they found to be suitable. If Rovus’s group has been there as long as you say, I think it is likely he will make a bridgehead there. Then the other Keltin will follow.
Other Star Men?
Legions, from across this universe. They wait with the Keltin Core.
What’s the Keltin Core?
A planet-sized piece of pure solonium. The birthplace of the Keltin. The Core is the place where the first Star Men were fashioned. Forged from solonium, shaped into their current form.
The physics of this world is very different from our own.
This solonium. When the Star Men have absorbed its energy, it becomes red coral.
So the Star Men, they’re the red coral in another form?
The highest form, possessed of great intellect — but in this they are merely agents of the Core. The Core is sentient. The Star Men are linked to it. The Core controls them, and gives them direction.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 145
If they depend on it, then the Core is their vulnerability.
Without the Core, they would cease to function. But it is protected.
I don’t see how we could do much about it anyway. I mean look at us. Stuck in a hole.
With no weapons and no ship.
We don’t even know where this Core is. Or the rift.
The rift is here.
What?!
The rift, the door to your universe, is here. I can show you.
(STANDING) Please! Yes.
(STANDING) Come with me.
What about those creatures? The Krail?
They are stupid. But we shall be careful.
THEY FOLLOW LOM OUT.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 146
129. INT. CONTROL SUITE.
A bridgehead?

It seems that’s the Star Men’s way. An advance party secures territory, and a larger group follows. It’s what they did by using the bodies of your dead to set up that first portal on this base. Preparing for their invasion.
An invasion? Of Gallius U?
I expect their ambitions reach much further than this planet.
Correct, Doctor.
You and your people might have won this base without a fight, but don’t expect humanity and the other races of this galaxy to be such a pushover.
He’s going to have some help. More of his kind. Rovus and his Star Men are just the vanguard.
And when this galaxy has been won we shall continue, to the next galaxy, and the next. This universe offers rich pickings. So many stars.
Others would stand in your way. The Daleks, for one.
All will be swept aside. Now, Doctor... The matter of your time machine.
I wondered when we’d come back to that...
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 147
130. EXT. HELIOPAN: SLOPE.
LOM, TEGAN, NYSSA AND NOMAR ON A RISING TRACK.
How much further to the rift, Lom?
Not far. To the top of this rise.
Nyssa. This rift — you think it might be our way back?
I don’t see how we can hope to escape this universe otherwise.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 148
131. INT. CORRIDOR.
DOCTOR, ROVUS AND KALA WALKING.
When we reach your time machine, Doctor, you will open it — or I will kill the Controller.
Doctor...?
It won’t come to that, Kala. I hope.
APPEARS AT FAR END OF CORRIDOR.
(OFF) Hey! Star Man!
Adric?!
What’s he doing down the other end of the corridor?
Boy! Come here!
RUNS AFTER ADRIC.
(RUNNING) Bye!
(TO KALA) Taunting Rovus, it appears.
(OPPOSITE END OF CORRIDOR) Mother! Doctor! Here, quick!
Autumn? !
DOCTOR AND KALA AS THEY RUN TO AUTUMN. MEANWHILE:
(RUNNING) Boy! Stop! (STOPPING) Wait. What is this? (TURNS; SEES THE DOCTOR AND KALA RUNNING OFF) Doctor! Controller! Stay still! (BEGINS TO STOMP BACK)
Close the bulkhead, Autumn! Quickly!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 149
TAPS A KEYPAD AND A BULKHEAD SLAMS INTO PLACE.
ROARS WITH FRUSTRATION...
. AS BULKHEAD CLOSES, SEALING THE OTHERS OFF.
Well done!
Good teamwork, eh?
That bulkhead won’t stop Rovus for long.
THE BULKHEAD SHUDDERS WITH ENERGY FROM ROVUS’S ENERGY ASSAULT.
You’re right. Run!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 150
132. INT. CORRIDOR INTERSECTION.
DOCTOR, KALA AND AUTUMN RUN IN. ADRIC RUNS IN FROM ANOTHER DIRECTION.
Adric!
Hello, Doctor!
That was hideously dangerous.
(NUDGING DOCTOR) But very courageous!
Well, yes, I suppose so —
It worked, didn’t it?
We need to get out of sight.
More importantly, we need to get access to the base computer system.
The Astronomy Hub?
Lead on.
THEY RUN OFF.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 151
133. INT. CORRIDOR.
WALKS ALONG. ROVUS STRIDES TOWARDS HIM.
Vedrin! The Doctor and the Controller have escaped!
Escaped?!
I’ll tear this place apart to find them. Return to the nebula. Be prepared to send the signal when I give the word.
Understood.
HURRIES AWAY.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 152
134. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB.
DESERTED. THE DOCTOR, KALA, ADRIC AND AUTUMN HURRY IN.
Here we are. The Astronomy Hub.
Excellent!
I take it you’ve got a plan?
You know me, Adric.
Then what is it?
First things first. The orbital telescope was knocked out by the Kepler. Is there any other way to observe the Tarantula Nebula in detail?
How much detail?
Enough for a spectrographic and gravitational analysis.
Only the orbital telescope could do that. We’re in the wrong aspect for the ground observatory to get that view.
Pity. In fact, disastrous.
Hang on. Are you after live data, or would historical do?
If historical is within the last few weeks.
We have a cached record of recent readings from the Nebula.
Perfect!
Here.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 153
TAPS A KEYBOARD. IMAGES AND DATA APPEAR ON A SCREEN.
This was four days ago.
Can you isolate star cluster R one-three-six?
TAPS KEYBOARD.
What are you looking for?
Anomalies in mass, gravity, radiation, light wave emissions... Adric?
Yes?
Could you look at gravity and mass equations? See if you can spot anything unusual - anything that doesn’t fit.
Right!
TAKES A SEAT, STARTS WORK AT ANOTHER KEYBOARD.
Autumn, if you could punch up the spectrographic and radiographic readings...
Sure.
What’s all this for, Doctor?

Rovus is expecting more of his people. They have to come through somewhere, but the portals they make are too small. My theory is that there’s a tear in space — a rift in the Tarantula Nebula. The R one-three-six cluster is the most likely area.
Doctor! I’ve got something!
Show me.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 154
Look - there’s a gravitational dip somewhere around that supergiant, see?
Meaning something in that area of space is reducing the gravity from the supergiant.
This rift of yours.
Very probably. An opening into the universe of the Star Men. That’s where their invasion will come from!
But can it be closed?
Well, I have friends on the other side, and I’d like them back first. But possibly, perhaps with a very large explosion... Before that, however, we have to find out precisely where it is.
Well, how do we do that?
We’d have to get access to one of the Star Men’s portals. The one by the TARDIS won’t be easy to get to.
There’s another portal in the Science Hub. We can check the camera network to see if they’ve left it unguarded.
In which case... Adric?
Yes?
How would you like to put your space navigation training into practice?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 155
135. EXT. HELIOPAN: SLOPE.
LOM, NOMAR, TEGAN AND NYSSA REACH A CREST. HEARD FAINTLY, FAR OFF, A BURNING SCAR IN THE SKY.
There. You see it now.
That’s the rift?
(CRESTFALLEN) It’s in the sky..!
In space. It’s huge.
Did you think it would be on the surface?
I’d hoped it might be a way home. Like one of those portals.
It might as well be on the other side of this universe.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 156
136. INT. CORRIDOR 4M.
THE DOCTOR, KALA AND ADRIC — WHO’S WEARING A SURVIVAL SUIT WITHOUT THE HELMET — BESIDE THE HUMMING PORTAL.
Here’s the portal. You know what to do, Adric?
Through the portal, straight through three chambers, turn left and I’m outside the citadel.
You’11l see assault ships in the valley. Use one of them to navigate to the R one-three-six cluster. When you get there, the onboard systems will guide you to the rift.
Got it.
All I want you to do is find the exact location. Nothing else. No heroics. Come back with the co-ordinates.
Doctor, if Tegan and Nyssa are through that rift...
No heroics! We’1ll get them back, but I don’t want to lose you too. Understood?
(RELUCTANT) Understood.
If I’m successful here, we’ll have plenty of time to get Tegan and Nyssa.
I’d better be off... (PUTS ON AND LOCKS HIS HELMET) (D) Good luck.
And you.
(HELMET DISTORT) Bye!
HE LEAPS THROUGH THE PORTAL AND IS GONE.
Now what’s this plan you’ve got in mind?
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
First, I’ll take a sample of — [coral]
RUNS IN WEARING A SURVIVAL SUIT.
Has Adric gone?
Autumn, what are you doing in that suit?
(PUTS ON HELMET) I’m going with Adric!
You are not!
(HELMET DISTORT) Sorry, Mother! I have to!
Autumn! No!
Page 157
See you soon!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 158
137. INT. CITADEL CHAMBER. [CONTINUOUS]
LEAPS IN THROUGH THE PORTAL.
D) (LANDING EFFORT
(D) Autumn?? You shouldn’t be here!
(D) I couldn’t leave you. On your own, I mean. Shall we go?
(D) (RESIGNED) We’ve got to be quick. Follow me!
138. EXT. CITADEL.
WINDS BLOWING A GALE AS ADRIC AND AUTUMN EMERGE ONTO THE PLAIN.
(D) There are the ships.
(D) Third one from the left is General Fell’s. Race you!
AN ENERGY BLAST RIPS UP THE GROUND NEXT TO THEM.
ADRIC and AUTUMN: (D) (STARTLED) Aah!!
(OFF) Stop there!
(D) We’ve been spotted! Run!
ENERGY SHOTS HIT THE GROUND AS THEY RACE OFF.
CHASES THEM, STILL SHOOTING.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL)
139. INT. CORRIDOR 4M.
HUMMING AS THE DOCTOR CHIPS AT A PIECE OF
What are you doing with the coral?
Collecting a piece of it.
It’s dangerous.
As the Star Men will discover, so am I.
HE PULLS A CHUNK OF CORAL FREE.
Let’s get this to the Astronomy Hub.
THEY HURRY OFF.
Page 159
CORAL.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 160
140. EXT. PLANETOID: PLAIN.
ADRIC AND AUTUMN RUNNING IN SURVIVAL SUITS. ENERGY BLASTS ERUPT
THEM.
(D) Inside the ship! Quickly!
THEY RUN UP THE RAMP OF FELL’S ASSAULT SHIP.
(D) We made it!
141. INT. ASSAULT SHIP: COCKPIT. [CONTINUOUS]
ADRIC AND AUTUMN RUN IN, REMOVING HELMETS. INTO FLIGHT SEATS.
We need to get away from here, fast!
WORKS CONTROLS. ENGINES POWER ON.
You’re sure you can fly this?
I understand all the principles.
That’s a “no”, then.
Hold on tight. (WRENCHES BACK ON FLIGHT YOKE)
THE CRAFT SHUDDERS WITH POWER AS IT LIFTS. CROSS TO:
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 161
142. EXT. PLANETOID: PLAIN.
AS THE SHIP SOARS AWAY, VEDRIN OPENS A COMMS CHANNEL.
Imperator Rovus, can you hear me?
(D) What is it, Vedrin?
Two humans appeared at the Citadel. They’ve taken one of the vessels on the plain.
(D) They may threaten the crossing. Send the signal, Vedrin! Tell the fleet to come through!
At once!
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 162
143. INT. ASSAULT SHIP: COCKPIT.
IN SPACE FLIGHT.
COMPLETES A CONTROL SEQUENCE.
I’ve set course for the star cluster. When we’re closer, we should get a good reading on that gravity dip.
If you concentrate on flying, I'll watch for that.
Thanks. And Autumn...
Yes?
I know I said you shouldn’t be here. But.. I’m really glad you came.
(BRIGHTLY) Me too.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 163
144. EXT. HELIOPAN.
We should start back.
Yeah, enough of the sight-seeing. Besides I prefer the aurora australis - this thing’s too big for the eyes.
THEY RETURN DOWN THE SLOPE. KRAIL BEASTS SHRIEK. THE GROUP STOPS.
Krail beasts!
They must have followed our trail.
We’ll have to take another route back. Over the top of the ridge. Hurry.
THEY SCRAMBLE BACK UP THE SLOPE. MORE SHRIEKS FROM THE KRAIL.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 164
145. INT. ASTRONOMY HUB.
THE DOCTOR WORKING ON CONTROLS.
So what are you going to do with that piece of coral?
Test a theory. The Star Men have an affinity with the coral. They use it for food, for fuel, and as a means to kill and control their victims.
So?
I think their affinity is at the molecular level. That the Star Men and the red coral have the same base structure.
Is it alive? I thought corals were dead - the husks of marine creatures.

‘Coral’ refers to both the substance and the creature that makes it - more properly called a coelenterate [see-LENTER- ate]. All corals are alive. A Star Man may well be the red coral in its ultimate form, transfused with enormous amounts of energy. That’s why the coral responds to technology. It changes its form when exposed to a power source. Like the radiation field from this hand scanner...
What are you doing?!
THE DOCTOR SWITCHES ON THE SCANNER AND IT BUZZES. THE RED CORAL CRACKS AND BECOMES GASEOUS, HISSING.
Energised, it becomes gaseous. On the other hand, when you cool it.. (HEFTS CYLINDER, AND...)
. HE FIRES A JET OF VAPOUR AT THE CORAL. STINGING HISS AS CORAL HARDENS TO A SOLID.
It turns back to solid form.
Becomes inert, exactly. One burst of coolant took the energy out of it.
#221: THE STAR MEN by Andrew Smith (FINAL) Page 165
Then the Star Men can be stopped!
